title: Google\Cloud\Datastore\DatastoreClient
name: DatastoreClient
description:
Google Cloud Datastore is a highly-scalable NoSQL database for your applications. Find more information at the Google Cloud Datastore docs.

Cloud Datastore supports multi-tenant applications through use of data partitions. A partition ID can be supplied when creating an instance of Cloud Datastore, and will be used in all operations executed in that instance.

To enable the Google Cloud Datastore Emulator, set the DATASTORE_EMULATOR_HOST environment variable.

examples.caption: Multi-tenant applications can supply a namespace ID.
Using the Datastore Emulator

methods.name: __construct
methods.description: Create a Datastore client.

params.name: config.apiEndpoint
params.description: A hostname with optional port to use in place of the service's default endpoint.

params.name: config.projectId
params.description: The project ID from the Google Developer's Console.

params.name: config.authCache
params.description: A cache for storing access tokens. Defaults to a simple in memory implementation.

params.name: config.authHttpHandler
params.description: A handler used to deliver Psr7 requests specifically for authentication.

params.name: config.httpHandler
params.description: A handler used to deliver Psr7 requests. Only valid for requests sent over REST.

params.name: config.keyFile
params.description: The contents of the service account credentials .json file retrieved from the Google Developer's Console. Ex: json_decode(file_get_contents($path), true).

params.name: config.keyFilePath
params.description: The full path to your service account credentials .json file retrieved from the Google Developers Console.

params.name: config.requestTimeout
params.description: Seconds to wait before timing out the request. Defaults to 0 with REST and 60 with gRPC.

params.name: config.retries
params.description: Number of retries for a failed request. Defaults to 3.

params.name: config.scopes
params.description: Scopes to be used for the request.

params.name: config.quotaProject
params.description: Specifies a user project to bill for access charges associated with the request.

params.name: config.namespaceId
params.description: Partitions data under a namespace. Useful for Multitenant Projects.

params.name: config.returnInt64AsObject
params.description: If true, 64 bit integers will be returned as a Google\Cloud\Core\Int64 object for 32 bit platform compatibility. Defaults to false.

methods.name: key
methods.description: Create a single Key instance

examples.caption: To override the internal detection of identifier type, you can specify which type to use.

params.name: options.identifierType
params.description: If omitted, type will be determined internally. In cases where any ambiguity can be expected (i.e. if you want to create keys with name but your values may pass PHP's is_numeric() check), this value may be explicitly set using Key::TYPE_ID or Key::TYPE_NAME.

methods.name: keys
methods.description:
Create multiple keys with the same configuration.

When inserting multiple entities, creating a set of keys at once can be useful. By defining the Key's kind and any ancestors up front, and allowing Cloud Datastore to allocate IDs, you can be sure that your entity identity and ancestry are correct and that there will be no collisions during the insert operation.

params.name: kind
params.description: The kind to use in the final path element.

params.name: options.ancestors
params.description: An array of PathElement arrays. Use to create ancestor paths.

methods.name: entity
methods.description:
Create an entity.

This method does not execute any service requests.

Entities are created with a Datastore Key, or by specifying a Kind. Kinds are only allowed for insert operations. For any other case, you must specify a named key. If a kind is given, an ID will be automatically allocated for the entity upon insert. Additionally, if your entity requires a complex key elementPath, you must create the key separately.

In complex applications you may want to create your own entity types. Google Cloud PHP supports subclassing of Google\Cloud\Datastore\Entity. If the name of a subclass of Entity is given in the options array, an entity will be created with that class rather than the default class.

examples.caption: Entity values can be assigned and accessed via the array syntax.
Entity values can also be assigned and accessed via an object syntax.
Entities can be created with a Kind only, for inserting into datastore
Entities can be custom classes implementing the Datastore entity interface.
Custom entity types may also extend the built-in Entity class.
If you wish to exclude certain properties from datastore indexes, property names may be supplied in the method $options:

params.name: key
params.description: The key used to identify the record, or a string $kind. The key may be null only if the entity will be used as an embedded entity within another entity. Attempting to use keyless entities as root entities will result in error. Defaults to null.

params.name: entity
params.description: The data, provided as an array of keys and values to fill the entity with. Defaults to [].

params.name: options.className
params.description: If set, the given class will be returned. Value must be the name of a class implementing Google\Cloud\Datastore\EntityInterface. Defaults to Google\Cloud\Datastore\Entity.

params.name: options.excludeFromIndexes
params.description: A list of entity keys to exclude from datastore indexes.

methods.name: geoPoint
methods.description: Create a new GeoPoint

methods.name: blob
methods.description: Create a new Blob

examples.caption: Blobs can be used to store binary data

params.name: value
params.description: The value to store in a blob.

methods.name: int64
methods.description: Create an Int64 object. This can be used to work with 64 bit integers as a string value while on a 32 bit platform.

methods.name: cursor
methods.description:
Create a Cursor.

A cursor points to a position within a set of entities. Cloud Datastore uses Cursors for paginating query results.

methods.name: allocateId
methods.description:
Allocates an available ID to a given incomplete key

Key MUST be in an incomplete state (i.e. including a kind but not an ID or name in its final pathElement).

This method will execute a service request.

methods.name: allocateIds
methods.description:
Allocate available IDs to a set of keys

Keys MUST be in an incomplete state (i.e. including a kind but not an ID or name in their final pathElement).

This method will execute a service request.

methods.name: transaction
methods.description: Create a Transaction.

methods.name: readOnlyTransaction
methods.description: Create a Read-Only Transaction.

methods.name: insert
methods.description:
Insert an entity

An entity with incomplete keys will be allocated an ID prior to insertion.

Insert by this method is non-transactional. If you need transaction support, use Google\Cloud\Datastore\Transaction::insert().

methods.name: insertBatch
methods.description:
Insert multiple entities

Any entity with incomplete keys will be allocated an ID prior to insertion.

Insert by this method is non-transactional. If you need transaction support, use Google\Cloud\Datastore\Transaction::insertBatch().

methods.name: update
methods.description:
Update an entity

Please note that updating a record in Cloud Datastore will replace the existing record. Adding, editing or removing a single property is only possible by first retrieving the entire entity in its existing state.

Update by this method is non-transactional. If you need transaction support, use Google\Cloud\Datastore\Transaction::update().

params.name: options.allowOverwrite
params.description: Entities must be updated as an entire resource. Patch operations are not supported. Because entities can be created manually, or obtained by a lookup or query, it is possible to accidentally overwrite an existing record with a new one when manually creating an entity. To provide additional safety, this flag must be set to true in order to update a record when the entity provided was not obtained through a lookup or query. Defaults to false.

methods.name: updateBatch
methods.description:
Update multiple entities

Please note that updating a record in Cloud Datastore will replace the existing record. Adding, editing or removing a single property is only possible by first retrieving the entire entity in its existing state.

Update by this method is non-transactional. If you need transaction support, use Google\Cloud\Datastore\Transaction::updateBatch().

params.name: options.allowOverwrite
params.description: Entities must be updated as an entire resource. Patch operations are not supported. Because entities can be created manually, or obtained by a lookup or query, it is possible to accidentally overwrite an existing record with a new one when manually creating an entity. To provide additional safety, this flag must be set to true in order to update a record when the entity provided was not obtained through a lookup or query. Defaults to false.

methods.name: upsert
methods.description:
Upsert an entity

Upsert will create a record if one does not already exist, or overwrite existing record if one already exists.

Please note that upserting a record in Cloud Datastore will replace the existing record, if one exists. Adding, editing or removing a single property is only possible by first retrieving the entire entity in its existing state.

An entity with incomplete keys will be allocated an ID prior to insertion.

Upsert by this method is non-transactional. If you need transaction support, use Google\Cloud\Datastore\Transaction::upsert().

methods.name: upsertBatch
methods.description:
Upsert multiple entities

Upsert will create a record if one does not already exist, or overwrite an existing record if one already exists.

Please note that upserting a record in Cloud Datastore will replace the existing record, if one exists. Adding, editing or removing a single property is only possible by first retrieving the entire entity in its existing state.

Any entity with incomplete keys will be allocated an ID prior to insertion.

Upsert by this method is non-transactional. If you need transaction support, use Google\Cloud\Datastore\Transaction::upsertBatch().

methods.name: delete
methods.description:
Delete an entity

Deletion by this method is non-transactional. If you need transaction support, use Google\Cloud\Datastore\Transaction::delete().

params.name: options.baseVersion
params.description: Provides concurrency control. The version of the entity that this mutation is being applied to. If this does not match the current version on the server, the mutation conflicts.

methods.name: deleteBatch
methods.description:
Delete multiple entities

Deletion by this method is non-transactional. If you need transaction support, use Google\Cloud\Datastore\Transaction::deleteBatch().

params.name: options.baseVersion
params.description: Provides concurrency control. The version of the entity that this mutation is being applied to. If this does not match the current version on the server, the mutation conflicts.

methods.name: lookup
methods.description:
Retrieve an entity from the datastore

To lookup an entity inside a transaction, use Google\Cloud\Datastore\Transaction::lookup().

params.name: key
params.description: The identifier to use to locate a desired entity.

params.name: options.className
params.description: If set, the given class will be returned. Value must be the name of a class implementing Google\Cloud\Datastore\EntityInterface. Defaults to Google\Cloud\Datastore\Entity.

methods.name: lookupBatch
methods.description:
Get multiple entities

To lookup entities inside a transaction, use Google\Cloud\Datastore\Transaction::lookupBatch().

params.name: options.className
params.description: If a string, the given class will be returned. Value must be the name of a class implementing Google\Cloud\Datastore\EntityInterface. If an array is given, it must be an associative array, where the key is a Kind and the value must implement Google\Cloud\Datastore\EntityInterface. Defaults to Google\Cloud\Datastore\Entity.

params.name: options.sort
params.description: If set to true, results in each set will be sorted to match the order given in $keys. Defaults to false.

returns.description: Returns an array with keys [found, missing, and deferred]. Members of found will be instance of Google\Cloud\Datastore\Entity. Members of missing and deferred will be instance of Google\Cloud\Datastore\Key.

methods.name: query
methods.description:
Create a Query object.

The Query class can be used as a builder, or it can accept a query representation at instantiation.

methods.name: gqlQuery
methods.description:
Create a GqlQuery object.

Returns a Query object which can be executed using Google\Cloud\Datastore\DatastoreClient::runQuery().

examples.caption: Literals must be provided as bound parameters by default:
While not recommended, you can use literals in your query string:

params.name: options.allowLiterals
params.description: Whether literal values will be allowed in the query string. Parameter binding is strongly encouraged over literals. Defaults to false.

params.name: options.bindings
params.description: An array of values to bind to the query string. Queries using Named Bindings should provide a key/value set, while queries using Positional Bindings must provide a simple array. Query cursors may be provided using instances of Google\Cloud\Datastore\Cursor.

methods.name: runQuery
methods.description:
Run a query and return entities

To query datastore inside a transaction, use Google\Cloud\Datastore\Transaction::runQuery().

params.name: options.className
params.description: If set, the given class will be returned. Value must be the name of a class implementing Google\Cloud\Datastore\EntityInterface. Defaults to Google\Cloud\Datastore\Entity.
